author: adaviel
body:
I'm new to powershell. I've been told I need to install MSOnline to allow powershell to authenticate to Azure/AD.

I have powershell-6.0.0_beta.9-1.rhel.7.x86_64 on CentOS 7.4.1708

Running as root:
**PS /root> Import-Module MSOnline                                                                                                  
Import-Module : The specified module 'MSOnline' was not loaded because no valid module file was found
PS /root> Install-Module MSOnline -Force                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Installing package 'MSOnline'**  

Get-Module lists nothing new, no files have appeared in /opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-beta.9/Modules/ or in /root/.local/share/powershell/Modules, and Import-Module still fails

**PS /root> Save-Module -Name MSOnline -Path /root/tmp
WARNING: Administrator rights are required to install or update.
PackageManagement\Save-Package : Unable to save the module 'MSOnline'.**

A directory /root/tmp/MSOnline/1.1.166.0/ is created, but it's empty.

a) is there a way to make install work ?
b) why is it saying I need administrator rights if I'm running as root ?
c) is there a way to download modules manually and copy them into the .local directory ?

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
Hi @adaviel!

The [MSOnline](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/msonline/?view=azureadps-1.0) is the older module for managing Azure AD. The newer module is [AzureAD](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/Azuread/?view=azureadps-2.0). Neither module is supported on Linux platforms. They are currently only supported by Windows PowerShell 5.1 on Windows Platforms.

In the future, those modules may be made available in PowerShell Core and on Linux, but for the time being they are not supported on linux.

comments.author: adaviel
comments.body:
So you are saying that Azure would not work even if I could install it.

Does anything actually work ?
E.g. if I try to install ACMESharp or Pscx it behaves in the same way - appears to download, but cannot be imported.

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
Correct. if you could download and install them they would still not function on Linux. I believe the AzureAD Module doesn't work on PowerShell Core on windows either due to it's reliance on ADAL which requires WinForms. 

There are quite  a few modules that will work with Core and on Linux. You could try some from the [PowerShellGallery](https://www.powershellgallery.com/items?q=Tags%3A%22PSEdition_Core%22) just to eliminate if it is something related to installations.

comments.author: adaviel
comments.body: As I say, I can't even seem to install them. I just tried psCheckPoint from your link, with the same results. Earlier, somehow in my playing around I did get MSOnline downloaded into the local modules directory - not sure how - but it did not show in Get-Module until I renamed it from MSOnline.1.1.166.0/ to just MSOnline/. Same with a utility "PsGet" I found online - the instructions said that PsGet.psm1 would work if placed in the Modules directory, but it had to be in a PsGet subdirectory.
